Grazulis|Thomas P.]], [[National Climatic Data Center|NCDC]] |- | {{sort|0408|Apr 8}} | {{dts|1998}} | {{dts|1842}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Alabama|AL]] | [[Oak Grove, Alabama|Oak Grove]]–[[Sylvan Springs, Alabama|Sylvan Springs]]–[[Pleasant Grove, Alabama|Pleasant Grove]]–[[Edgewater, Alabama|Edgewater]]–[[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] | {{nts|32}} | [[April 1998 Birmingham tornado]] – Many homes were swept away along the path.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.gov/bmx/event_04081998 |title=Tuscaloosa Tornado of 4/8/1998 |publisher=National Weather Service Birmingham, Alabama |accessdate=2013-07-13}}{{cite web |url=http://www.colorado.edu/hazards/research/qr/qr116/qr116.html |title=WARNING RESPONSE AND RISK BEHAVIOR IN THE OAK GROVE - BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA, TORNADO OF 08 APRIL 1998 |last1=Legates |first1=David |year=1999 |website=Colorado.edu |publisher=University of Oklahoma |accessdate=January 2, 2014}} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]], [[Thomas P. Grazulis|Thomas P.]], [[National Climatic Data Center|NCDC]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0416|Apr 16}} | {{dts|1998}} | 1550 | [[United States|US]] | [[Tennessee|TN]] | [[Hardin County, Tennessee|Hardin County]]–[[Wayne County, Tennessee|Wayne County]] | {{nts|3}} | [[1998 Nashville tornado outbreak]] – Originally considered part of a very long-tracked F5 tornado but was later determined to have been the first in a series of three separate, violent tornadoes. Multiple homes were reduced to their foundations. Although officially rated an F4, a re-analysis conducted in 2013 by the NWS Office in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] noted that the damage in Wayne County may warrant EF5; however, no tornadoes are rated using the enhanced scale that occurred prior to February 2007.{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Nashville, Tennessee|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=April 17, 2013|accessdate=October 23, 2013|title=April 16, 1998 Tornado Outbreak|url=https://www.weather.gov/ohx/19980416}} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0416|Apr 16}} | {{dts|1998}} | {{dts|1615}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Tennessee|TN]] | [[Wayne County, Tennessee|Wayne County]]–[[Lawrence County, Tennessee|Lawrence County]] | {{nts|0}} | [[1998 Nashville tornado outbreak]] – This tornado produced extreme damage at ground level. Many large and well-built homes with anchor bolts were swept away, and vehicles were thrown hundreds of yards. A swath of grass {{convert|200|ft|yd|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} wide was scoured from the ground, with nothing but bare soil and clumps of dirt remaining. | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]], [[Thomas P. Grazulis|Thomas P.]], [[National Climatic Data Center|NCDC]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0530|May 30}} | {{dts|1998}} | 2026 | [[United States|US]] | [[South Dakota|SD]] | [[Spencer, South Dakota|Spencer]] | {{nts|6}} | DOW recorded maximum wind speeds at {{convert|264|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} at 160 ft above ground level, which the NWS classified at almost ground level. Such wind speeds would fall well into the EF5 range on the Enhanced Fujita Scale, though the maximum damage intensity observed in the town of Spencer was F4. The town's water tower was toppled to the ground, an apartment building was leveled, and many homes were completely destroyed, a few of which were swept away.{{cite conference |url=https://extremeplanet.me/2012/07/03/highest-winds-measured-in-several-different-tornadoes/|title= The Highest Winds Ever Measured by Mobile Doppler Radar in Five Violent Tornadoes: |last1=Hagan|first1=Maximilian}} | [[Doppler on Wheels|DOW]], [[Joshua Wurman|Joshua]] |- | {{sort|0503|May 3}} | {{dts|1999}} | {{dts|1823}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Amber, Oklahoma|Amber]]–[[Bridge Creek, Oklahoma|Bridge Creek]]–[[Newcastle, Oklahoma|Newcastle]]–[[Moore, Oklahoma|Moore]]–[[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|Oklahoma City]]–[[Del City, Oklahoma|Del City]]–[[Midwest City, Oklahoma|Midwest City]] | {{nts|36}} | [[1999 Bridge Creek–Moore tornado]] – Mobile radar recorded winds up to {{convert|301|±|20|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, which is the highest wind speed ever measured on Earth. Many homes were swept completely away, some of which were well-bolted to their foundations, and debris from some homes was finely granulated. Severe ground and pavement scouring occurred, trees and shrubs were completely debarked, and vehicles were thrown up to {{convert|440|yd|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} from where they originated. An airplane wing was carried for several miles, and a {{convert|36000|lb|kg|sigfig=5|adj=on}} freight car was bounced 3/4 of a mile.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.gov/oun/events-19990503-storma |title=The Great Plains Tornado Outbreak of May 3-4, 1999 - Storm A Information |publisher=National Weather Service Norman, Oklahoma |accessdate=2013-08-31}}https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=5705284{{cite web|author1=Jim LaDue |author2=Tim Marshall |author3=Kevin Scharfenberg |last-author-amp=yes |work=National Weather Service Office in Norman, Oklahoma|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|year=2012|accessdate=June 26, 2013|title=Discriminating EF4 and EF5 Tornado Damage|url=https://www.yumpu.com/en/document/view/12309173/discriminating-ef4-and-ef5-tornado-damage|format=PDF}} This was the 50th and last tornado to be officially assessed as F5 on the Fujita scale before the introduction of the Enhanced Fujita Scale in the United States. | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]], [[Doppler on Wheels|DOW]], [[Joshua Wurman|Joshua]], [[Thomas P. Grazulis|Thomas P.]], [[National Climatic Data Center|NCDC]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0503|May 3}} | {{dts|1999}} | 2125 | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Mulhall, Oklahoma|Mulhall]] | {{nts|2}} | [[1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak]] – Officially rated high-end F4, rating disputed. Some wind velocities were recorded up to 260 mph (418 km/h), other were recorded between 265 and 297 mph (426 and 477 km/h). Dozens of structures were destroyed, including some that were swept away. Studies found that the debris cloud from the tornado possible reached 4.3 miles wide at times. Meteorologists have stated that this event was as violent or more violent than the Bridge Creek-Moore F5 earlier that day.{{cite web|url=http://www.stormeyes.org/tornado/3may99/|title=Central Oklahoma Tornado Intercept: 3 May 1999 (Roger Edwards)|website=www.stormeyes.org}} | [[Doppler on Wheels|DOW]], [[Joshua Wurman|Joshua]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0511|May 11}} | {{dts|1999}} | 1805 | [[United States|US]] | [[Texas|TX]] | [[Loyal Valley, Texas|Loyal Valley]] | {{nts|1}} | Officially rated high-end F4, though one survey revealed potential F5 damage.{{cite web |url=http://amarillo.com/stories/1999/05/14/tex_LO0722.001.shtml |title=Oklahoma-size tornado hits unpopulated Hill Country |last1=Richards |first1=Charles |date=May 14, 1999 |website=Amarillo.com |publisher=Amarillo-Globe News |accessdate=November 28, 2014}} Two homes were completely swept away, with the debris strewn long distances. Large pieces of a pickup truck were found 3/4 of a mile away from the residence where it originated, and a 720-foot long stretch of pavement was scoured from a road. Ground scouring occurred, and numerous mesquite trees were completely denuded and debarked.{{cite web|url=http://cig.mesonet.org/NCDCpubs/Storm_Data/1999%20SD/SD199905.pdf |title=Storm Data and Unusual Phenomenon-May 1999 |date=May 1999 |website=cig.mesonet.org |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=November 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311195101/http://cig.mesonet.org/NCDCpubs/Storm_Data/1999%20SD/SD199905.pdf |archivedate=March 11, 2014 |df= }} https://web.archive.org/web/20160303165045/http://amarillo.com/stories/1999/05/14/tex_LO0722.001.shtml | Pending |} ===2000–{{Currentyear}}=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |+ Officially and unofficially rated F5/EF5 tornadoes from 2000 to {{Currentyear}}{{#tag:ref||group="nb"|name="SPCF5"}} |- ! scope="col" style="width:5%;"| Day ! scope="col" style="width:4%;"| Year ! scope="col" style="width:4%;"| Time(LST) ! scope="col" style="width:4%;"| Country ! scope="col" style="width:4%;"| State ! scope="col" style="width:20%;" class="unsortable"| Location ! scope="col" style="width:4%;"| Fatalities ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes ! scope="col" style="width:5%;"| Listed F5 by |- |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0504|May 4}} | {{dts|2003}} | {{dts|1635}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Kansas|KS]] | [[Girard, Kansas|Girard]]–[[Franklin, Kansas|Franklin]] | {{nts|4}} | [[May 2003 tornado outbreak sequence]] – Officially rated high-end F4, but there is speculation that this tornado may have reached F5 intensity. Homes along the path were swept completely away, severe ground scouring occurred, and heavy objects and vehicles were thrown over {{convert|100|yd|ft|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} from where they originated. The town of Franklin sustained devastating damage, with multiple homes swept away.{{cite conference |title= Eric's Weather Library|url= https://ericsweatherlibrary.com/f5-tornado-chronology3/ F5 Tornadoes: The Chronology – Part III|last1=Brown|first1=Eric}} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]], [[Gino Izzi|Gino]] |- |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0624|June 24}} | {{dts|2003}} | {{dts|2003}} | [[United States|US]] | [[South Dakota|SD]] | [[Manchester, South Dakota|Manchester]] | {{nts|0}} | [[2003 South Dakota tornado outbreak]] – Officially rated high-end F4, but there is speculation that this tornado may have reached F5 intensity. In the National Weather Service survey released shortly after the tornado, winds were estimated to be up to 260 miles per hour. All three homes at Manchester were swept away, Tornado left cycloidal marks in farm fields, and trees in Manchester were debarked.https://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-magazine/2018/april/tim-samaras-storm-chaser/ | [[National Weather Service|NWS?]], [[Tim Samaras|Tim]] |- |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0512|May 12}} | {{dts|2004}} | {{dts|2040}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Kansas|KS]] | [[Harper, Kansas|Harper]] | {{nts|0}} | This tornado completely swept away an anchor-bolted farmhouse, leaving very little debris behind. Severe ground scouring occurred in the area, and nearby trees were completely debarked and denuded, some of which were ripped out of the ground and thrown long distances. Five cars on the property were thrown and torn to pieces, with very few automobile parts recovered besides several scraps of metal and some engine blocks scattered throughout nearby fields. Suspected by many to have been an F5, but was rated F4 due to the fact that the tornado was very slow-moving.{{cite web |url=https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=5391565 |website=NCDC Database |publisher=NCDC |access-date=February 27, 2018}}{{cite AV media |date=May 12, 2004 |title=Harper F-4 NWS Damage Survey Video |medium=Motion Picture |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xnw-VG5KUb0 |access-date=February 27, 2018 }} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0504|May 4}} | {{dts|2007}} | {{dts|2100}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Kansas|KS]] | [[Greensburg, Kansas|Greensburg]] | {{nts|11}} | [[Greensburg tornado|May 2007 tornado outbreak]] – This tornado destroyed 95% of the town, including seven well-built homes with anchor bolts that were swept away. Vehicles were thrown hundreds of feet, several freight train cars were overturned, and multi-ton oil tanks were destroyed. Trees were completely denuded and debarked as well.{{cite conference |url= https://ams.confex.com/ams/pdfpapers/141534.pdf|title= Damage survey of the Greensburg, KS tornado|last1=Marshall|first1=Timothy P. Marshall|last2=McCarthy|first2=Daniel|last3=LaDue|first3=James}} This was the first tornado to have been rated EF5 after the retirement of the original Fujita Scale in the United States in February 2007. Winds inside according to velocities were 230 knots (between 264 and 265 mph) making it well above the EF5 threshold. Also a field near town was heavily scoured. | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]], [[Timothy P. Marshall|Timothy P.]] |- | {{sort|0622|Jun 22}} | {{dts|2007}} | {{dts|1825}} | [[Canada|CA]] | [[Manitoba|MB]] | [[Elie, Manitoba|Elie]] | {{nts|0}} | [[Elie, Manitoba tornado]] – Two homes were swept away, including one that was well-bolted to its foundation. A few of the bolts themselves were snapped off. A van was thrown 150 metres through the air, and nearby trees were debarked as well.https://ams.confex.com/ams/pdfpapers/141718.pdf Only officially rated F5 tornado in Canada.[http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=4B3DE57E-4967-4B09-98D6-EF974B32D6B5 Elie Tornado Upgraded to Highest Level on Damage Scale: Canada's First Official F5 Tornado] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611150927/http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=4B3DE57E-4967-4B09-98D6-EF974B32D6B5 |date=2011-06-11 }} ''[[Environment Canada]]'' Accessed May 27, 2008. Last tornado to be rated F5 due to Environment Canada utilizing the Enhanced Fujita Scale on April 1, 2013. | [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|EC]] |- | {{sort|0525|May 25}} | {{dts|2008}} | {{dts|1648}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Iowa|IA]] | [[Parkersburg, Iowa|Parkersburg]]–[[New Hartford, Iowa|New Hartford]] | {{nts|9}} | [[Late-May 2008 tornado outbreak sequence]] – Well-built homes with anchor bolts were swept away, 17 of which were assessed to have sustained EF5 damage. Two of them had no visible debris left anywhere near the foundations.{{cite web|title=Details of the Parkersburg Storm Damage Survey|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/images/dmx/parkersburg/Parkersburg-Storm-Damage-Survey.pdf|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=September 8, 2013|location=Des Moines, Iowa}}https://ams.confex.com/ams/pdfpapers/141533.pdf A concrete walk-out basement wall was pushed over at one home, and the concrete floor was cracked. A rebar support set into the foundation of another home was found snapped in half, and reinforced concrete light poles were snapped and dragged along the ground. A large industrial building was completely destroyed, with metal beams twisted and sheared off at their bases, and the foundation pushed clean of the metal framing and debris. Vehicles were thrown long distances and stripped down to their frames as well. Additionally, a large field east of Parkersburg was filled with finely granulated debris that was wind-rowed in long streaks, trees were completely debarked, and shrubs were uprooted and stripped in some areas.{{cite web |url=http://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/cases/080525/dmx_parkersburg_damage/ |title=Parkersburg EF5 Damage |date=May 26, 2008 |website=http://mesonet.agron.iastate.edu/ |publisher=NWs Des Moines |accessdate=January 12, 2015}} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0427|Apr 27}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1430}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Mississippi|MS]] | [[Philadelphia, Mississippi|Philadelphia]]–[[Preston, Mississippi|Preston]] | {{nts|3}} | [[2011 Philadelphia, Mississippi tornado]] – Rated EF5 based upon extreme ground scouring. The tornado dug a trench {{convert|2|ft|m|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} deep into a pasture, leaving nothing but large clumps of dirt and bare topsoil behind.{{cite web|title=Neshoba/Kemper/Winston/Noxubee Counties Tornado|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/jan/?n=2011_04_25_27_neshoba_kemper_winston_noxubee|website=srh.noaa.gov|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=8 November 2014|location=[[Jackson, Mississippi]]}} A tied-down mobile home was lofted through the air and carried {{convert|300|yd|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}}, with no indication of contact with the ground. Several vehicles were tossed hundreds of yards and wrapped around trees, and a steel I-beam was twisted and embedded into the ground. Pavement was scoured from roads as well, and extreme debarking and denuding of trees occurred, some of which were ripped out of the ground and thrown up to 20 yards away. | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0427|Apr 27}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1540}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Mississippi|MS]]–[[Alabama|AL]] | [[Smithville, Mississippi|Smithville]]–[[Shottsville, Alabama|Shottsville]] | {{nts|23}} | [[2011 Smithville, Mississippi tornado]] – Numerous well-built, anchor-bolted brick homes were swept away, including one that had part of its concrete slab foundation pulled up and dislodged slightly. An SUV was thrown half a mile into the top of the town's water tower. In the most intense damage area, all plumbing and appliances at home-sites were "shredded or missing."{{cite web|title=Smithville, MS EF-5 Tornado|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/meg/?n=apr2011toroutbreaksmithville|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=14 April 2014|location=[[Memphis, Tennessee]]|date=30 May 2011}} Chip and tar pavement was torn from road, and a pickup truck that was thrown from one home was never recovered. A large brick funeral home was reduced to a bare slab, and extensive wind-rowing of debris occurred next to the foundation. Outside town, the ground was deeply scoured in an open field.{{cite web|url=http://ngs.woc.noaa.gov/storms/apr11_tornado/ |title=April 2011 Tornado Response Imagery |publisher=Ngs.woc.noaa.gov |accessdate=2013-09-15}} Additionally, numerous trees and low shrubbery were debarked and shredded.[http://www.srh.noaa.gov/srh/srnews/stories/2011/outbreak_smithvilleEF5.htm NWS Southern Region News - Smithville, Mississippi EF5 Tornado Damage]{{cite web|work=Richard Okulski|publisher=NWS Memphis, TN|date=October 17, 2011|accessdate=March 4, 2014|title=Smithville, MS Tornado presentation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fmI_2iYuchc}} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0427|Apr 27}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1505}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Alabama|AL]]–[[Tennessee|TN]] | [[Hamilton, Alabama|Hamilton]]–[[Hackleburg, Alabama|Hackleburg]]–[[Phil Campbell, Alabama|Phil Campbell]]–[[Tanner, Alabama|Tanner]]–[[Athens, Alabama|Athens]]–[[Harvest, Alabama|Harvest]]–[[Huntland, Tennessee|Huntland]] | {{nts|72}} | [[2011 Hackleburg–Phil Campbell, Alabama tornado]] – This was the deadliest tornado in Alabama state history. Numerous homes, some of which were large, well-built, and anchor-bolted were swept away. Debris from some obliterated homes was scattered and wind-rowed well away from the foundations.{{cite web|title=Hackleburg (Marion County) EF-5 Tornado April 27, 2011|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/bmx/?n=event_04272011hackleburg|website=srh.noaa.gov|publisher=[[National Weather Service]]|accessdate=8 November 2014|location=[[Birmingham, Alabama]]}}{{cite web|title=Franklin (AL) / Lawrence / Morgan / Limestone / Madison / Franklin (TN) EF-5|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/hun/?n=franklin-al_lawrence_limestone_madison_franklin-tn_counties|website=srh.noaa.gov|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=8 November 2014|location=[[Huntsville, Alabama]]}} One home that was swept away had its concrete stemwalls sheared off at ground level. Vehicles were thrown at least {{convert|200|yd|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}}, and at least one large vehicle that was missing after the tornado was never located. Hundreds of trees were completely debarked and twisted, and in some cases were reduced only to stubs. Pavement was scoured from roads as well, a large industrial plant was leveled to the ground, and a restaurant that was swept away had a small portion of its foundation slab torn apart.{{cite web |url=http://apps.dat.noaa.gov/StormDamage/DamageViewer/ |title=NWS Damage Assessment Toolkit |website=apps.dat.noaa.gov |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=June 23, 2014}} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0427|Apr 27}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1643}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Alabama|AL]] | [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]]–[[Holt, Alabama|Holt]]–[[Hueytown, Alabama|Hueytown]]–[[Concord, Alabama|Concord]]–[[Pleasant Grove, Alabama|Pleasant Grove]]–[[McDonald Chapel, Alabama|McDonald Chapel]]–[[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]]–[[Fultondale, Alabama|Fultondale]] | {{nts|64}} | [[2011 Tuscaloosa–Birmingham tornado]] – Officially rated high-end EF4, though the final rating was a source of controversy, and one survey team rated some of the damage as EF5. Many homes, a large section of an apartment building, and a clubhouse were swept away, though these structures were either poorly anchored, lacked interior walls, or surrounded by contextual damage not consistent with an EF5 tornado. A manhole cover was removed from a drain and thrown into a ravine near the clubhouse. A {{convert|34|t|lb|sigfig=5|adj=on}} railroad trestle support structure was thrown {{convert|100|ft|m|abbr=on}} up a hill, and a {{convert|35.8|t|lb|sigfig=5|adj=on}} coal car was thrown {{convert|391|ft|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} through the air. | [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0427|Apr 27}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1819}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Alabama|AL]]–[[Georgia (U.S. state)|GA]] | [[Fyffe, Alabama|Fyffe]]–[[Rainsville, Alabama|Rainsville]]–[[Sylvania, Alabama|Sylvania]]–[[Ider, Alabama|Ider]] | {{nts|25}} | [[2011 Super Outbreak]] – Many homes were swept away, some of which had their concrete porches torn away and shattered, with debris strewn up to a mile away from the foundations in some cases. A few of the homes were bolted to their foundations. An {{convert|800|lb|kg|sigfig=3|adj=on}} safe was ripped from its anchors and thrown {{convert|600|ft|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}}, and its door was ripped from its frame. Ground scouring occurred, and sidewalk pavement was pulled up. A pickup truck was tossed {{convert|250|yd|ft|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} and torn apart. An underground storm shelter had much of its dirt covering scoured away and was heaved slightly out of the ground, and pavement was scoured from roads. One well-built stone house was completely obliterated, and a stone pillar was ripped completely out of the ground at that residence, pulling up a section of house foundation in the process.{{cite conference |url= https://ams.confex.com/ams/26SLS/webprogram/Handout/Paper212695/sels12b.pdf|title=Extreme damage incidents in the 27 April 2011 tornado superoutbreak|last1=McCaul|first1=Eugene W.|last2=Knupp|first2=Kevin R.|last3=Darden|first3=Chris|last4=Laws|first4=Kevin}}{{cite web|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/hun/?n=4272011_dekalb_county |title=National Weather Service Huntsville, AL - DeKalb County Survey Information |publisher=Srh.noaa.gov |accessdate=2013-08-31}} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- |- style="background:#f4a460;" | {{sort|0522|May 22}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1734}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Missouri|MO]] | [[Joplin, Missouri|Joplin]]–[[Duquesne, Missouri|Duquesne]] | {{nts|158}} | [[2011 Joplin tornado]] – Deadliest tornado in the United States since 1947. Many homes, business, and steel frame industrial buildings were swept away, and large vehicles including semi-trucks and buses were thrown hundreds of yards. A large multi-story hospital had its foundation and underpinning system so severely damaged that it was structurally compromised and had to be torn down. Reinforced concrete porches were deformed, lifted, and tossed, and {{convert|300|lb|kg|sigfig=3|adj=on}} concrete parking stops anchored with rebar were ripped from parking lots and tossed well over {{convert|100|ft|m|sigfig=2|abbr=on}}. Vehicles were thrown several blocks away from the residences where they originated, and a few were never recovered. Damage to driveways was noted at some residences as well. A large steel-reinforced concrete "step and floor structure" leading to one building was warped slightly and cracked.{{cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/sgf/?n=event_2011may22_survey |title=National Weather Service Springfield, MO - Event Review - May 22, 2011 |publisher=Crh.noaa.gov |accessdate=2013-08-31}} Ground and pavement scouring occurred, and heavy manhole covers were removed from roads as well. On June 10, 2013, an engineering study found no evidence of EF5 structural damage in Joplin due to the poor quality of construction of many buildings. However, the EF5 rating stood as the National Weather Service in [[Springfield, Missouri]], stated that survey teams found only a very small area of EF5 structural damage (at and around the hospital) and that it could have easily been missed in the survey, and the EF5 rating was mainly based on large vehicles being thrown long distances, along with non-conventional, non-structural instances of damage, such as removal of manhole covers, pavement, concrete porches, driveways, and parking stops, and the presence of wind-rowed debris.[http://www.weather.com/news/tornado-central/new-engineering-study-finds-no-ef5-damage-joplin-20130610 New Engineering Study Finds No EF5 Damage in Joplin - weather.com]{{cite web |url=https://ams.confex.com/ams/26SLS/webprogram/Paper211981.html |title=Supplemental Damage Indicators Discovered in Recent Strong Tornadoes |last1=Sarkar |first1=Parka |last2=Marshall |first2=Timothy |date=November 7, 2012 |website=ams.confex.com |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=}} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0524|May 24}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1550}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Hinton, Oklahoma|Hinton]]–[[Calumet, Oklahoma|Calumet]]–[[El Reno, Oklahoma|El Reno]]–[[Piedmont, Oklahoma|Piedmont]]–[[Guthrie, Oklahoma|Guthrie]] | {{nts|9}} | [[Tornado outbreak sequence of May 21–26, 2011]] – Mobile radar recorded winds over {{convert|200|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}. Many homes were swept away, trees were completely debarked, and extensive ground scouring occurred. At the Cactus 117 oil rig, a {{convert|1,900,000|lb|kg|sigfig=5|adj=on}} oil derrick was blown over and rolled three times. Cars were thrown long distances and wrapped around trees, including an SUV that was thrown {{convert|780|yd|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} and had its body ripped from the frame. Several cars near the beginning of the path were thrown more than {{convert|1,093|yd|mi|sigfig=2|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |url=https://ams.confex.com/ams/26SLS/webprogram/26SLS.html |title=Performance of residences and shelters in the Oklahoma tornadoes of 24 May 2011 |last1=Marshall |first1=Timothy |last2=Ladue |first2=Jim |date=2011 |website=ams.confex.com |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=August 29, 2014}}[http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=events-20110524-tornado-b2 Tornado B2 - The Calumet-El Reno-Piedmont-Guthrie Tornado of May 24, 2011] Additionally, a {{convert|20,000|lb|kg|sigfig=4|adj=on}} oil tanker truck was thrown approximately {{convert|1|mi|km|sigfig=2|abbr=on}}.{{cite conference|url=https://ams.confex.com/ams/92Annual/flvgateway.cgi/id/19926?recordingid=19926|title=Overview of the 24 May 2011 tornado outbreak|last=Ortega|first=Kiel}}{{cite AV media |people=Gardner, Jim |date= May 24, 2011 |title=Tornado Hits Producing Location-Oklahoma |trans-title=|medium=motion picture |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7dfzLj3u5n4&NR=1 |accessdate= January 20, 2014 |time= |publisher=KFOR |location=Oklahoma |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0524|May 24}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1706}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Chickasha, Oklahoma|Chickasha]]–[[Blanchard, Oklahoma|Blanchard]]–[[Newcastle, Oklahoma|Newcastle]] | {{nts|1}} | [[Tornado outbreak sequence of May 21–26, 2011]] – Officially rated a high-end EF4; however, the survey conducted by NWS Norman mentions this tornado as being a "plausible EF5". Well-built homes with anchor bolts were swept away, pavement was scoured from roads and driveways, and vehicles were thrown up to {{convert|600|yd|m|sigfig=3|abbr=on}} away, some of which were torn into multiple pieces or stripped down to their frames. Trees were reduced to completely debarked stumps, and severe ground scouring occurred, with all grass and several inches of topsoil removed in some areas. A reinforced concrete dome home was severely damaged and cracked.{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Norman, Oklahoma|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=July 12, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2013|title=The Chickasha-Blanchard-Newcastle Tornado of May 24, 2011|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=events-20110524-tornado-c1}}{{cite web |url=https://apps.dat.noaa.gov/StormDamage/DamageViewer/ |title=Damage Assessment Toolkit |date=May 24, 2011 |website=apps.dat.noaa.gov |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=August 30, 2014}} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0524|May 24}} | {{dts|2011}} | {{dts|1726}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Bradley, Oklahoma|Bradley]]–[[Dibble, Oklahoma|Dibble]]–[[Washington, Oklahoma|Washington]]–[[Goldsby, Oklahoma|Goldsby]] | {{nts|0}} | [[Tornado outbreak sequence of May 21–26, 2011]] – Officially a high-end EF4, but rating is disputed. Large and well-built homes with anchor bolts were swept completely away, extensive ground scouring occurred, and vehicles were thrown long distances and mangled almost beyond recognition.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=315875 |title=Storm Events Database - Event Details | National Climatic Data Center|work=National Climatic Data Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=2011-05-24 |accessdate=2013-09-15}}{{cite web |url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=events-20110524-tornado-d1 |title=The Washington-Goldsby Tornado of May 24, 2011 |website=NWS Norman, OK |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=August 31, 2014}} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- | {{sort|0520|May 20}} | {{dts|2013}} | {{dts|1456}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Newcastle, Oklahoma|Newcastle]]–[[Moore, Oklahoma|Moore]] | {{nts|24}} | [[2013 Moore tornado]] – Many homes were swept away, including nine that were well-built and bolted to their foundations and two elementary schools were completely destroyed.{{cite web |url=https://ams.confex.com/ams/94Annual/webprogram/Handout/Paper241554/828_sls_ortega_et_al_moore_tornado.pdf |title=Damage Survey and Analysis of the 20 May 2013 Newcastle-Moore, OK, EF-5 Tornado (Presentation) |last1=Marshall |first1=Tim |last2=Ortega |first2=Kiel |date=February 5, 2014 |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=March 12, 2014}} Extensive ground scouring occurred with only bare soil left in some areas, and a 10-ton propane tank was thrown more than half a mile through the air. Trees and shrubs were completely debarked, wind-rowing of debris was noted, and an oil tank was thrown a full mile from a production site, while another was never found.{{cite web|publisher=National Weather Service Norman, Oklahoma|date=May 21, 2013|accessdate=May 23, 2013|title= The Tornado Outbreak of May 20, 2013|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=events-20130520}}{{cite web |url=https://ams.confex.com/ams/94Annual/webprogram/Paper241554.html |title=Damage Survey and Analysis of the 20 May 2013 Newcastle-Moore, OK, EF-5 Tornado |last1=Marshall |first1=Tim |last2=Ortega |first2=Kiel |date=February 5, 2014 |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=March 12, 2014}} A manhole cover was removed near Moore Medical Center, and vehicles were thrown hundreds of yards and torn into multiple pieces.{{cite web |url=https://apps.dat.noaa.gov/StormDamage/DamageViewer/ |title=Damage Assessment Toolkit |date=May 20, 2013 |website=apps.dat.noaa.gov |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=November 25, 2014}}{{cite AV media |people=Welch, Trevor |date= May 20, 2014 |title=May 20th, 2013 Oklahoma tornado damage about 1 hour after |trans-title=|medium=motion picture |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zjFhz-fxGK4 |accessdate= September 4, 2014 |time= |publisher=Trevor Welch |location=Moore, Oklahoma |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} | [[Storm Prediction Center|SPC]], [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0531|May 31}} | {{dts|2013}} | {{dts|1803}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[El Reno, Oklahoma|El Reno]] | {{nts|8}} | [[2013 El Reno tornado]] – Largest tornado on record at {{convert|2.6|mi|km|}} wide. Was initially rated EF5 based solely on mobile Doppler radar measurements, which recorded winds over {{convert|295|mi/h|km/h|sigfig=2|abbr=on}}. However, the most significant structural damage was rated EF3, as the tornado did not strike any buildings when the EF5 winds were recorded. Rating was eventually downgraded to EF3 because of this, though the practicality of the downgrade has been disputed by some meteorologists. Famous storm chaser [[Tim Samaras]] is one of the fatalities.{{cite web |url=http://earthsky.org/earth/why-was-el-reno-oklahoma-tornado-downgraded-to-ef-3 |title=Why was El Reno, Oklahoma tornado downgraded to EF3? |last1=Forbes |first1=Greg |last2=Daniel |first2=Matt |date=September 5, 2013|website=EarthSky.org|publisher=unknown|accessdate=November 5, 2013}}https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=453682 | [[National Centers for Environmental Information|NCEI]], [[Center for Severe Weather Research|CSWR]], [[Doppler on Wheels|DOW]], [[Joshua Wurman|Joshua]], [[University of Oklahoma RaXPol radar|OU RaXPol]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0427|Apr 27}} | {{dts|2014}} | {{dts|1906}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Arkansas|AR]] | [[Mayflower, Arkansas|Mayflower]]–[[Vilonia, Arkansas|Vilonia]] | {{nts|16}} | [[Tornado outbreak of April 27–30, 2014]] – Officially rated high-end EF4, though the rating was a major source of controversy, and meteorologist/civil engineer [[Timothy P. Marshall]] noted that the rating assigned was "lower-bound", and also noted "the possibility that EF5 winds could have occurred" despite the structural flaws responsible for the EF4 rating.{{cite web |url=https://ams.confex.com/ams/27SLS/webprogram/Paper254346.html |title= Damage Survey of the Mayflower-Vilonia, Arkansas Tornado |last1=Marshall |first1=Timothy |date=November 6, 2014 |website=ams.confex.com |publisher=American Meteorological Society |accessdate=December 11, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.arktimes.com/ArkansasBlog/archives/2014/05/05/meteorologist-defends-ef4-rating-on-vilonia-tornado |title=Meteorologist defends EF4 rating on Vilonia tornado |last1=Brantley |first1=Max |date=May 5, 2014 |website=Arkansas Times |publisher=Arkansas Times |access-date=March 4, 2015}} Numerous homes were swept completely away with only bare slabs left, including one that was well-bolted to its foundation, and extensive wind-rowing of debris occurred. Trees were completely debarked and denuded, shrubs were shredded and debarked, and vehicles were thrown hundreds of yards and stripped down to their frames. A large 29,998-pound metal fertilizer tank was found approximately 3/4 of a mile away from where it originated.{{cite web|work=National Weather Service Office in Little Rock, Arkansas|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=May 1, 2014|accessdate=May 2, 2014|title=April 27, 2014 Arkansas tornado surveys|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/images/lzk/gis/tor042714a.kml|format=.KML}}{{cite web |url=http://darkroom.baltimoresun.com/2014/04/aerial-assessment-of-southern-states-tornado-damage/#1 |title=Aerial assessment of southern states tornado damage |last1=Gordon |first1=Kalani |date=April 30, 2013 |website=The Dark Room |publisher=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=March 4, 2014}} Extensive ground scouring occurred as well.{{cite web |url=http://thecabin.net/latest-news/2014-04-28/video-aerial-footage-mayflower-violnia-tornado#.VQMjzY7F-oy |title=Video: Aerial footage of Mayflower, Vilonia tornado |date=April 28, 2014 |website=thecabin.net |publisher=The Log Cabin Democrat |access-date=March 13, 2015}} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]], [[Timothy P. Marshall|Timothy P.]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0509|May 9}} | {{dts|2016}} | {{dts|1634}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Oklahoma|OK]] | [[Davis, Oklahoma|Davis]]–[[Sulphur, Oklahoma|Sulphur]]–[[Roff, Oklahoma|Roff]] | {{nts|0}} | [[Tornado outbreak of May 7–10, 2016]] – This large wedge tornado produced high-end EF3 damage along its path, though mobile Doppler radar recorded winds over {{convert|218|mi/h|km/h|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} as the tornado was passing over an open field.https://apps.dat.noaa.gov/StormDamage/DamageViewer/ https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=633084 | [[National Centers for Environmental Information|NCEI]], [[Center for Severe Weather Research|CSWR]], [[Doppler on Wheels|DOW]] |- style="background:#fdaf9a;" | {{sort|0525|May 25}} | {{dts|2016}} | {{dts|1907}} | [[United States|US]] | [[Kansas|KS]] | [[Solomon, Kansas|Solomon]]–[[Abilene, Kansas|Abilene]]–[[Chapman, Kansas|Chapman]] | {{nts|0}} | [[Tornado outbreak sequence of May 22–26, 2016]] – An anchor-bolted brick farm home was swept away and was ripped from its foundation so violently that part of the foundation was severely cracked, though the area surrounding the home was not swept completely clean. Vehicles and large pieces of farm machinery were thrown and mangled beyond recognition, and a section of metal railroad track was bent horizontally by the tornado. Officially rated very high-end EF4 with winds of 200 mph (320 km/h), though NWS Topeka damage surveyors later noted that based on the severity of the damage in rural areas, it "could have very well been" rated EF5 had it struck Chapman directly.{{cite AV media |people=Omitt, Chad |date= February 19, 2016 |title=Tornado Talk Podcast Episode 29 - Top 10 of 2016 Part 2 (Enhanced Version) |medium=motion picture |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tvOTNoraTEI |accessdate= November 5, 2017}} | [[National Weather Service|NWS]] |} ==See also== * [[Tornado intensity and damage]] * [[List of tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] * [[List of tornadoes striking downtown areas]] * [[Tornado myths]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== *{{cite book|last=Grazulis|first=Thomas P.|title=Significant Tornadoes, 1680-1991: A Chronology and Analysis of Events|year=1993|publisher=Environmental Films|location=[[St. Johnsbury, Vermont]]|isbn=1-879362-03-1}} *{{cite book|author=—|title=The Tornado: Nature's Ultimate Windstorm|year=2001|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3538-0}} ==External links== * [http://www.spc.noaa.gov/faq/tornado/f5torns.html F5 Tornadoes in the U.S. since 1950 (SPC/NOAA)] * [http://www.tornadohistoryproject.com/tornado/F5 U.S. F5 tornadoes] - Tornado History Project * [http://www.tornadoproject.com/ The Tornado Project] * [http://www.nssl.noaa.gov/users/brooks/public_html/concannon/ Climatological Risk of Strong and Violent Tornadoes in the United States (Paper 9.4, Second Conference on Environmental Applications)] * [http://www.nssl.noaa.gov/hazard/ Severe Thunderstorm and Tornado Climatology (NSSL)] * [http://www.tornadoproject.com/cellar/fscale.htm Fujita Scale] ===Canadian sources=== * [http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/environment/extreme-weather/ Extreme Weather at the CBC.ca Archives] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070202091718/http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/environment/naturalhazards/majortornadoes/tornadoes_stats_new.html List of strong tornadoes from 1879 to present] {{DEFAULTSORT:F5 And Ef5 Tornadoes}} [[Category:F5 tornadoes| ]] [[Category:Tornado-related lists]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Phaeocollybia'' species}} This is a list of species in the [[agaric]] genus ''[[Phaeocollybia]]''.
==Key== {| class="wikitable" style="width: 100%;" |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"| Name |The [[binomial name]] of the ''Phaeocollybia'' species. |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"| Authority |The [[Author citation (botany)|author citation]]—the person who first [[species description|described]] the species using an available scientific name, eventually combined with the one who placed it in ''Phaeocollybia'', and using standardized abbreviations. |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"|Year |The year in which the species was named, or transferred to the genus ''Phaeocollybia''. Where the actual year of publication (as defined for the purpose of [[Principle of Priority|priority]]) differs from the printed date, the date as given on the reference is given in quotes. |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"|Distribution |The geographical distribution of the species. |}

page.title: List of countries by oil consumption

revision.comment: Greenland is a part of Denmark.
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=February 2014}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2012}} }} [[File:EIA petroleum consumption of selected nations 1960-2008.png|thumb|upright=2|Petroleum: top consuming nations, 1960–2008]] [[File:OilConsumptionpercapita.png|thumb|upright=2|A map of world oil consumption in barrels a day per capita, 2007. {{refbegin|3}} {{legend|#800000| > 0.07}} {{legend|#a52a2a|0.07 - 0.05}} {{legend|#ff0000|0.05 - 0.035}} {{legend|#fa8072|0.035 - 0.025}} {{legend|#f08080|0.025 - 0.02}} {{legend|#ffb6c1|0.02 - 0.015}} {{legend|#ffebda|0.015 - 0.01}} {{legend|#ffebcf|0.01 - 0.005}} {{legend|#fff8dc|0.005 - 0.0015}} {{legend|#e6e6fa| < 0.0015}} {{refend}}]] [[File:World oil consumption 1980 to 2007 by region.svg|thumb|upright=2|Daily oil consumption by region from 1980 to 2006.]] The total worldwide [[oil consumption]] is 93 million bbl/day according to the [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA).{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/aboutus/faqs/oil/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230233305/http://www.iea.org/aboutus/faqs/oil/ |archivedate=2013-12-30 |df= }}{{when|date=April 2017}} == Trends == In 2010, [[world energy consumption]] of refined products increased 3.8%;[http://yearbook.enerdata.net/ Energy Statistics] which was the first increase since 2004. According to [https://web.archive.org/web/20110321034717/http://www.enerdata.net/enerdatauk/ Enerdata], this trend was supported by fast-growing demand for [[road transport|road]] and [[air transport]], particularly in [[developing countries]]. In [[China]], demand for refined products surged by 12% due to increasing needs. Asia accounted for more than 40% of the overall increase in consumption. In [[Latin America]], demand rose sharply by 5.7%, representing 13% of the increase. In [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]], consumption grew by 7.3% (8.9% in Russia), while rising 4.2% in the [[Middle East]] (driven by Saudi Arabia and Kuwait). Each region contributed 8% to the overall increase. Despite this growth, the US remains by far the largest user of oil, consuming more than China in 2010. China may overtake the US around 2030. {{cite web|title=BP Energy Outlook 2035|url=http://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/Energy-economics/Energy-Outlook/Energy_Outlook_2035_booklet.pdf|page=38|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140402013418/http://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/Energy-economics/Energy-Outlook/Energy_Outlook_2035_booklet.pdf|archivedate=2014-04-02|df=}} == Countries == {{update|date=September 2015}} This is a '''list of countries by [[petroleum|oil]] [[Consumption (economics)|consumption]].''' {{cite web | url=https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/en/corporate/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review/bp-stats-review-2018-full-report.pdf | title=Statistical Review of World Energy, June 2018| accessdate=21 June 2018}}[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2246rank.html Country Comparison::Refined Petroleum Products - Consumption] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- style="font-size:88%" ! [[File:ThreeGorgesDam-China2009.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|[[Three Gorges Dam]], currently the [[#Hydroelectric|largest hydroelectric]] power station, and the largest power producing body ever built, at {{nowrap|22,500 [[Megawatt|MW]]}}]] This article lists the '''largest [[Electricity generation|power]] stations in the world''', the ten overall and the five of each type, in terms of current installed electrical [[Nameplate capacity|capacity]]. [[Non-renewable resource|Non-renewable]] power stations are those that run on [[coal]], [[fuel oil]]s, [[Nuclear power|nuclear]], [[natural gas]], [[oil shale]] and [[peat]], while [[Renewable resource|renewable]] power stations run on fuel sources such as [[biomass]], [[Geothermal power|geothermal heat]], [[hydroelectricity|hydro]], [[solar power|solar energy]], [[Solar thermal energy|solar heat]], [[Tidal power|tides]], [[Wave power|waves]] and the [[Wind power|wind]]. Only the most significant fuel source is listed for power stations that run on multiple sources. At present, the largest power generating facility ever built is the [[Three Gorges Dam]] in [[China]]. The facility generates power by utilizing 32 [[Francis turbine]]s each having a capacity of {{nowrap|700 MW}} and two {{nowrap|50 MW}} turbines, totalling the installed capacity to {{nowrap|22,500 MW}}, more than twice the installed capacity of the largest nuclear power station, the [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant|Kashiwazaki-Kariwa]] (Japan) at {{nowrap|7,965 MW}}. As of 2017 no power station comparable to Three Gorges is under construction, as the largest under construction power stations are hydroelectric [[Baihetan Dam]] ({{nowrap|16,000 MW}}){{cite web|title=A Brief History of Hydropower Development Baihetan |url=http://nn.lsz.gov.cn/lry.asp?id=164 |publisher=Baihetan China – Ningxia County Public Information Network |accessdate=20 March 2011 |date=2 December 2009 |language=zh |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823083909/http://nn.lsz.gov.cn/lry.asp?id=164 |archivedate=23 August 2011 |df= }} and [[Belo Monte Dam]] ({{nowrap|11,233 MW}}).{{Citation|title=Elekotrobras: Belo Monte|url=http://www.eletrobras.com/elb/main.asp?View=%7B46763BB8-3B05-432F-A206-C8F93CC3BA90%7D|format=PDF|accessdate=16 August 2012|language=pt}} Although currently only a proposal, the [[Grand Inga Dam]] in [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|the Congo]] would surpass all existing power stations, including the Three Gorges Dam, if construction commences as planned. The design targets to top {{nowrap|39,000 MW}} in installed capacity, nearly twice that of the Three Gorges.{{Citation|title=Africa plans biggest dam project, the Grand Inga|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7358542.stm|work=BBC News|date=21 April 2008|accessdate=21 March 2010}}{{Citation|title=Development of the Grand Inga|url=http://www.internationalrivers.org/en/africa/grand-inga-grand-illusions|accessdate=21 March 2010}}{{Citation|title=Grand Inga Dam|url=http://www.internationalrivers.org/en/node/345|accessdate=21 March 2010}} Another proposal, [[Penzhin Tidal Power Plant Project]], presumes an installed capacity up to {{nowrap|87,100 MW}}. == Top 20 largest power producing facilities == {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! page.title: List of protected areas of Roskilde Municipality

revision.text:
This '''list of protected areas of Roskilde Municipality''' is a list of protected areas of [[Roskilde Municipality]], [[Denmark]]. It is based on a list compiled by the [[Danish Society for Nature Conservation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.dk/Default.aspx?ID=25348|title=Fredede områder i Roskilde kommune|publisher=Danmarks Naturfredningsforening|accessdate=13 January 2015 |language=Danish}} The list comprises all localities that are under landscape protection. For heritage listed buildings, see the list of [[listed buildings in Roskilde Municipality]]. ==List== {|class="wikitable sortable" ! Image ! Locality ! Size ! Year ! Coordinates ! Description ! Source |- | | Bolund | c. 20 hs | 1941 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/bolund/ Ref] |- | [[File:Boserup Skov, Roskilde.jpg|75px]] | Boserup Skov and Kattinge Lakes | | 1964/1980 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/boserup-skov-og-kattingesoeerne/ Ref] |- | | [[Folkeparken, Roskilde|Folkeparken]] | 12 ha | 1972 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/folkeparken-klostermarken/ Ref] |- | | Gadstrup Church | | | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/gadstrup-kirke/ Ref] |- | | Gundsømagle Lake | 370 ha | 1953/1956/1094 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/gundsoemagle-soe/ Ref] |- | | [[Himmelev#Surroundings|Himmelev Strand]] | Ca. 0.37 ha | 1926/1953 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/himmelev-strand/ Ref] |- | | [[Jyllinge#Surroundings|Jyllinge Nordmark]] (Lønager Strandpark) | 3.7 ha | 1975 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/jyllinge-nordmark-loenager-strandpark/ Ref] |- | | Masterhøj | | 1918 | | | [http://www.fredninger.dk/fredning/masterhoej/ Ref] |- | | [[Jyllinge#Surroundings|Oddestenskysten]]

[[File:Agave americana R01.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Agave americana|maguey]] was cultivated by the [[Aztec]]s for its numerous uses including construction, fibre, hedging and production of the sacred drink [[pulque]].<ref>{{citation |title=Encyclopedia of Cultivated Plants |editor=Christopher Cumo |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2013 |isbn=9781598847758 |page=5}}</ref>]] This page contains a '''list of useful plants''', meaning a plant that has been or can be co-opted by humans to fulfill a particular need. Rather than listing all plants on one page, this page instead collects the lists and categories for the different ways in which a plant can be used; some plants may fall into several of the categories or lists below, and some lists overlap (for example, the term "crop" covers both edible and non-edible agricultural products).
